abstract.p: CUNY Graduate Center Gallery to host exhibition of photos by archaelogist Esther Boise Van Deman; San Francisco Symphony to present concerts of works by Italian maverick composers and Pan-American mavericks, San Francisco; exhibition set to open at Metropolitan Museum of Art's Costume Institute presents beauty and fashion as war with human body that results in bizarre and comical shapes; Emmylou Harris and others to perform at concert organized by Harris to benefit Afghan land mine victims; Jazz Alliance International plans concert to benefit World Trade Center relief; photos (M)

block.p: An American in Rome Esther Boise Van Deman was born in Ohio in 1862 and arrived in Rome in 1901 to study archaeology at the American School of Classical Studies, now the American Academy in Rome. She was among the first women to achieve wide recognition in Roman archaeology, and as a self-taught photographer she took thousands of pictures of her findings. The CUNY Graduate Center Gallery at 365 Fifth Avenue, at 34th Street, is the host of ''Esther Boise Van Deman: An Archaeologist's Eye,'' opening Thursday and continuing to Jan. 18. Information: (212) 817-7394.

'Mavericks' Goes Global Michael Tilson Thomas's ''American Mavericks'' programs of contemporary music have been a staple of the San Francisco Symphony's summer season since 1996. Now he has expanded the idea for the orchestra's regular season with ''Italian Mavericks'' this week and ''Pan-American Mavericks'' next week. The Italians, to be heard in concerts tomorrow through Saturday at the orchestra's home in Davies Symphony Hall, include Giacinto Scelsi and Luciano Berio as well as two who haven't been thought of as mavericks in a very long time, Monteverdi and Respighi. Next week the orchestra will scan the Americas with works by Henry Brant, Astor Piazzolla and Heitor Villa-Lobos. Information: (415) 864-6000.

Beauty ''Extreme Beauty: The Body Transformed,'' a new exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, is organized in a rational system: neck and shoulders, hips, waist, bust, feet. But the costumes on display -- a metal corset, Thierry Mugler's so-called ''motorcycle'' bustier -- present beauty and fashion as a war with the human body that results in bizarre and comical shapes. The exhibition of some 100 items in the museum's Costume Institute opens Thursday and runs through March 3. Information: (212) 535-7710.

Jazz and Country Benefits Two years ago Emmylou Harris organized her first concert for a land-mine-free world. She has since taken the idea on tour and released a live album to benefit the Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation's program to aid victims of land mines. Now, with an eye to the troubles in Afghanistan, Ms. Harris takes her tour to the Beacon Theater on Friday with Steve Earle, Bruce Cockburn, Mary Chapin Carpenter and Patty Griffin. . . . On Wednesday at Town Hall the nonprofit group Jazz Alliance International will present ''Made in America,'' a benefit for World Trade Center relief with an attractive lineup of jazz stars. Among the highlights are collaborations, among them Wayne Shorter and Rub√©n Blades, Cassandra Wilson and Bela Fleck, and Michael Brecker and John Scofield. Others on the bill include Kenny Barron, Terence Blanchard, K. D. Lang, Joe Lovano, Brad Mehldau, Kenny Garrett and Christian McBride. Tickets for both concerts: (212) 307-7171.
